title: Drive away bad luck in Hua Hin
text:
Drive away bad luck in Hua Hin 24 Sep 2015 at 03:47 96 viewed 0 comments NEWSPAPER SECTION: LIFE | WRITER: PICHAYA SVASTI - + From Saturday to Sunday, the annual "Merit Making, Boat Procession, Floating Bad Luck Away" festival will be held on the beach near the Chao Mae Tubtim Shrine on Naresdamri Road in downtown Hua Hin. 
Dolls for the boat procession in Hua Hin. 
The tradition has been carried out by communities of fishermen in Hua Hin for generations in the 10th lunar month of every year in order to make merit for ancestors and other spirits revered by fishermen, and to float away bad luck. This year, the procession of ritual boats and parade of long drum dancers and kratua taeng sua dancers will take to the streets of Hua Hin on Saturday, starting from 3pm. Participants can donate money as they want and will, in return, receive dolls on which they can write their names and place the dolls on the boat, which will be floated into the sea on Sunday at noon. Call the organiser Nanthapol Jiralapaspreeda on 032-513-436/7. Cycling in Bung Kan 
On Sunday, the "2nd Tour of Isan Bung Kan Classic" cycling tournament will take place on two different routes along tourist attractions in Bung Kan province. The races are hosted by the Tourism Authority of Thailand and Bung Kan province. 
The first route for mountain bikes is about 50km long and ends at Phu Sing Mountain. The second route for road bikes is 100km long and ends at Phu Thok Mountain. Both races are open to people of all ages. In each race, the first 10 finishers will obtain trophies. All the other finishers will receive a special T-shirt each. Registration begins at 6am. The races start at 7am and end at noon. Application fee is 500 baht per person. For more information, email isanbike@gmail.com or call Assadej Phuyim on 02-640-6270, 02-247-3796 or 095-874-5428. Community talks in Bangkok 
On Oct 4, the "Residents of Old Bangkok District" talk will be held near Mahakan Fort in Phra Nakhon district from 9am-noon with support from Lek-Prapai Viriyaphan Foundation. Admission is free. 
The talks will focus on the state of pedestal tray making in Ban Phan alley. Speakers are La-orsri Ratchata-silpa, a former schoolteacher and the heiress of the community's most important silversmith and pedestal tray-making family; Rattana Kanchanadul from a pedestal tray-making family; and Pimsiri Suwannakhon, leader of Trok Ban Phan Thom Community. 
There will also be an exhibition entitled, "Ban Phan Alley: Silver Pedestal Trays, Not Lacquerware Pedestal Trays", a display of silver pedestal trays and other silver masterpieces, as well as the sale of books, food and souvenirs. For more information, visit www.lek-prapai.org or call 02-281-1988. Saffron robe preparation 
From Oct 30-Nov 21, the annual Chullakathin saffron robe preparation and presentation ceremonies will be held at several temples in the Northeast. 
Chullakathin is a robe presentation ceremony that requires the unity of many Buddhists to collect cotton, weave, sew, dye and present a set of saffron robes to a monk within one day. According to ancient belief, Chullakathin is a great way to make merit since it requires much more effort than an ordinary kathin ceremony. Nowadays, only Chullakathin ceremonies take place in the North and Northeast. 
In Mukdahan province, the first ceremony will be performed at Wat Matchimawas in Don Tan district during Oct 30-Nov 1. The second one will take place at Wat Srinantharam in Ban Phu, Nong Sung district, on Nov 13-15. In Nakhon Ratchasima, the ceremony will be held at Thammada Forest Monastery at Ban Khum Ma Ou-Suan Mon in Bua Lai district on Nov 8. In Ubon Ratchathani, the ceremony will be performed at Wat Chaimongkol in Muang district from Nov 19-21. Visit www.facebook.com/go2isan or contact the TAT Call Centre 1672.
